title: RCE when removing metadata with ExifTool

profile.name: GitLab
profile.about: A single application for the entire software development lifecycle.

vulnerability_information:
### Summary
When uploading image files, GitLab Workhorse passes any files with the extensions [jpg|jpeg|tiff](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v13.10.2-ee/workhorse/internal/upload/exif/exif.go#L104) through to [ExifTool](https://exiftool.org/) to remove any non-whitelisted tags.

An issue with this is that ExifTool will ignore the file extension and try to determine what the file is based on the content, allowing for any of the supported parsers to be hit instead of just JPEG and TIFF by just renaming the uploaded file.

One of the supported formats is [DjVu](https://github.com/exiftool/exiftool/blob/11.70/lib/Image/ExifTool/DjVu.pm). When parsing the DjVu annotation, the [tokens are evaled](https://github.com/exiftool/exiftool/blob/11.70/lib/Image/ExifTool/DjVu.pm#L233) to "convert C escape sequences". 

There is some validation to try and ensure that everything is properly escaped, but a backslash followed by a newline is correctly handled allowing the quotes to be closed and arbitrary perl inserted and evaluated:

```
(metadata
	(Copyright "\
" . qx{echo vakzz >/tmp/vakzz} . \
" b ") )
```

{F1257008} is an example DjVu file with the above metadata, and {F1257009} is an example that runs a reverse shell.

### Steps to reproduce
1. Download {F1257008} and unzip it
1. Create a new snippet
1. In the description field, hit "Attach a file"
1. Select and uplaod `echo_vakzz.jpg`
1. See that the file `/tmp/vakzz` has been created on the server


Uploading {F1257009} to https://gitlab.com/-/snippets/new resulted in a shell on `web-09-sv-gprd`:

```
Connection from [34.74.90.73] port 12345 [tcp/*] accepted (family 2, sport 17073)

uid=500(git) gid=500(git) groups=500(git)
hostname -a

```


### Impact
* Anyone with the ability to upload an image that goes through the GitLab Workhorse could achieve RCE via a specially crafted file

### Examples
{F1257008}
{F1257009}

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
GitLab Workhorse will pass any file to ExifTool, greatly increasing the attack surface. The current bug is in the DjVu module of `ExifTool` which should ideally not ever be hit.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
* There must be better ways of convert C escape sequences than using `eval`
* Only the TIFF and JPEG modules should be used
* GitLab Workhorse could check if the file is a valid TIFF of JPEG before passing it to ExifTool

### Output of checks
This bug happens on GitLab.com

#### Results of GitLab environment info

* Anyone with the ability to upload an image that goes through the GitLab Workhorse could achieve RCE via a specially crafted file

activities.message:
I haven't reported this to https://exiftool.org/ yet (not exactly sure even where or how), it may need some kind of coordinated disclosure instead of just submitting it to the public bug tracker?

Cheers,
Will

Hello again @vakzz,

Thank you for submitting this report. Feeling a Déjà Vu here both with the file format and with your report from a few weeks ago. :)

We have verified this finding and have escalated to our engineering team.  We will be tracking progress internally at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/327121.  This issue will be made public 30 days following the release of a patch.

Given the severity of the report, we are paying an initial $1000 on triage. Congratulations!

We will continue to update you via HackerOne as a patch is scheduled for release.

Best regards,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team

Hello @vakzz,

Can you share what was the username of the GitLab account you used to upload the PoC please?

Thanks,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team
Ah it appears to be `vakzz-h1`, thanks.

Hi @dcouture,

Yep https://gitlab.com/vakzz-h1 is the one I used, the uploaded file ended up being rejected so not sure if anything was saved or not.

Cheers,
Will

Hello again @vakzz,

Did you intend to report this issue with the DJVU format to the ExifTool project? Would you rather we do it (in your name)? I suppose this might not be the only bug bounty report you get from this. :)

Best regards,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team

Hi @dcouture,

If you are able to handle reporting the issue that would be great :) 

Cheers,
Will

Hello again,

A GitLab team member had already reached out to ExifTool before I started my day today. I'll make sure you are credited for the vulnerability.

The bug was mitigated on .com yesterday, we are working on a longer term fix now and will have a new release available soon.

Thanks,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team

Hi @dcouture,

Thanks for the update!

Cheers,
Will

ETA for fix:

Hi @vakzz,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2021-05-31.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi @vakzz,

Thank you again for the report! Your finding has been patched in GitLab version 13.10.3 and we are awarding a bounty. Congratulations!

Please let us know if you find that our patch does not mitigate your finding. Your report will be published in 30 days in GitLab's issue tracker.

ExifTool independently patched the issue but they didn't intend to request a CVE or credit you in the release notes. We are independently requesting a CVE ID at the moment to help raise awareness about this issue.

We look forward to your next report!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Thanks in no small part to your recent findings, we are rolling back our policy about paying half-bounties for third party findings. These have great impact on GitLab and we want to continue to incentivize research for high+ severity issues in that area.

I don't know if you had any 50% bounties under that policy yourself, but we'll soon revisit the bounties we awarded during that period and pay out the full value.

Hi @dcouture,

> Thanks in no small part to your recent findings, we are rolling back our policy about paying half-bounties for third party findings. These have great impact on GitLab and we want to continue to incentivize research for high+ severity issues in that area.
> 
> I don't know if you had any 50% bounties under that policy yourself, but we'll soon revisit the bounties we awarded during that period and pay out the full value.

Wow amazing, thanks! I think the only other one was the issue last month, but that had a bonus to bring it up to the max already :)

> ExifTool independently patched the issue but they didn't intend to request a CVE or credit you in the release notes. We are independently requesting a CVE ID at the moment to help raise awareness about this issue.

Yeah I saw they released a new version with a fix, but it wasn't pushed to MetaCPAN so will make it hard for people to update. Also without a CVE the distros might not update their packaged version, so thanks for following that up!

Cheers,
Will

Hi @dcouture,

> We are independently requesting a CVE ID at the moment to help raise awareness about this issue.

Any updates on this? Not sure how long it normally takes, there are a couple of other vendors asking if there is a CVE for the issue is why I'm checking :)

Cheers,
Will

Hello @vakzz,

It was assigned `CVE-2021-22204` a few hours ago, it will be actually published soon.

Best regards,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team
That CVE was for ExifTool itself, the GitLab bug as reported here will be `CVE-2021-22205`.

Hi @dcouture,

Awesome thanks for that!

Cheers,
Will

Hi @dcouture,

My self-hosted Ultimate license has expired, would I be able to get it renewed or a new one? :) 

Cheers,
Will

Hi @vakzz,

I requested a new license and it should be sent to your @wearehackerone.com email address. If you haven't receive it in a week please let me know.

Thanks,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team
